title: Ticket #3097: fix vulnerability to DNS-lookup delays
description:
Ben Cotton observed a case where a schedd melted down (i.e. failed to keep up with shadows) because an entry in the flocking list was not a valid DNS name. Presumably, the failing lookup kept taking a lot of time, but the schedd just kept doing it anyway.

The death spiral began when a lot of these delays happened in a row. We saw this in the logs: 

06/28/12 16:50:02 (pid:18733) Failed to start non-blocking update to unknown.
06/28/12 16:50:51 (pid:18733) Failed to start non-blocking update to unknown.
06/28/12 16:51:44 (pid:18733) Failed to start non-blocking update to unknown.
06/28/12 16:52:39 (pid:18733) Failed to start non-blocking update to unknown.
06/28/12 16:53:29 (pid:18733) Failed to start non-blocking update to unknown.
06/28/12 16:54:23 (pid:18733) Failed to start non-blocking update to unknown.
06/28/12 16:55:06 (pid:18733) Failed to start non-blocking update to unknown.
06/28/12 16:56:02 (pid:18733) Failed to start non-blocking update to unknown.

Condor daemons already do some blacklisting of collectors that take a long time to fail. That is when querying. Perhaps the same needs to happen when publishing.

A deeper fix would be to never block on DNS lookups.
remarks:
2012-Jun-29 09:52:48 by bcotton:
I would also add that it would be beneficial if the log message were more clear about what's going wrong (e.g. which host name is failing to resolve). This could make identification of the problem quicker. Although it's less important if things continue working, it is useful information for administrators to have.

2012-Jul-02 11:22:44 by tannenba:
Ben - What specifically did you have in your flocking list that caused the DNS blocking? Could you add it to the ticket (or just email it to me if you don't want it publicly visible) ?

I ask because typically DNS NXDOMAIN errors (i.e. domain or host does not exist) do not cause any blocking, and are also typically cached by the resolver, so I am wondering how to easily reproduce this bug. Maybe some DNS servers have some sort of denial of service protection and slows down responses about non-existent hosts...

2012-Jul-02 15:49:00 by bcotton:
The host in question is condor.calumet.purdue.edu
